About five O'Clock on Saturday morning steam
carriage, carrying nearly dozen of persons inside
and out, made its appearance on the Camden town
road. 1t proceeded through Kentish tswn and up
Highgate Hill, at the rate, as nearly as could CAL
culate, of 81 miles an hour, its velocity being the
same in ascending the hill the comparatively
level ground.-upon arriving at the summit Of the
hill opposite Holy terrace, the conductor turned his
ponderous vehicle, and Immediately commenced the
descent of the hill. at rate perhaps of four miles an
hour. Whether, however, arising from the unskl-
fulness of the manager, or from the defect of the
machinery, we cannot tell, his pace became gradu-
ally much greater, until the power of controlling its
impetus seeming to be almost lost, it was propelled
so violently over paved gutter, that one of the
wheels gave way and put an immediate termination
to its further progress by steam A horse was then
procured, and the machine dragged away upon its
five remaining wheels. We believe this is the first
steam carriage that has been brought fairly into ac-
ton before the public. In size it undoubtedly ap
pears unwiedy compared with the common stage
coach, being somewhat more broad and nearly twice


the length Of those vehicles; but it appeared. not


withstanding its bulk to be thoroughly under the con-
troll of the steerer until the disorder of the machine


ry, the weight of the body, proved too heavy for
the wheels.

has finished her education. I" Observe Miss Prs-
sy with her hair , popilale, her slippers slip shod
her calico morning gown unhookeds her eyes halt
closed,and her mouth in the sulks slide to the break
fast table at 9o'clock. "She has finished her edu-


cation" See that young lady loling on the bed and
Icryng over novel. s.She has finished her educa-
ton" Only mark the fine bold, independent air
which Miss Dashaway puts on-she sails through
the drawing rooms--a nod to one-a smile to anoth-
ler-Mary how de do. when do you marrya Bless
us quadrille. Bennett play go to the devil and
shake yourself" Engaged sir, for the next six
cotillions." "She has finished her education." OBJ
serve that young lady at the piano, drumming the
march in the Freyschutz and squalling out of all
tune and harmony ana voche or Love was once
little boy."-"S She has finished her educaton.'


The fact is that young ladies of the present day,


finish their education before they have actually com
menced. They mistake the mere elementary and
introductory part of their education for the com
mencement, when in fact the commencement may
be dated from that period when mind and faculty
ldevelope themselves and embrace in cninprehens-
i've manner all the details and items of early in
Istruction, giving to each, force, stability and finish


Iii before the flower puts forth its genial buds,
that it is taken from the parent stalk, and though
admired and caressed for time, it soon withers.


The Liverpool Albion, in noticing this subject, re-
marks


.'lhere is lady of whom have some knowledge,
that finished her education,' by leaving peculiarly
good advantages at an early age. She is now
wife and the mother of six children. She plays
well upon the piano-sngs sweety-dances elegant
ly-is very polite, &c.-but her husband must, and
actually does. put all the children to bed and takes
care of them through the night and as to her ia
BILE. the bread is execrabe, to one who has visited
his grandmother's pantry-and her cohee--O her
coffee lit would cost her head, if the very scent
Of it reached the Grand Turks paace--andyet the
lady has ..taishea her education"

Education.--If there be not now less of crime
in country, taking into view the great increase
of population, than in preceding generations, there
more abhorrent features. And this is the conse-
quence of that advanced state of civilization and
generous culture of the moral virtues, which are
sure to result from the genial influence of education
diitused among all classes. The mind in early you'll,
imbued with a proper sense of moral right and OF
that sacred regard for the life and property of ano


her which religion SO strongly ncucates, will rare
ly he found debased by crime and more rarely by
crimes ofsanguinary hue. How important then is it
that every possible effort be made. to extend the
benefits of education to each and every inhabitant
! Of our country.


We wish to- see the community at large fully i'm.
pressed with the Importance, both in a moral and
political point Of view, Of the universal diffusion Of

The following declaration Of, or perhaps plea for,
Independence, is made by the editor Of the Norfolk
Herald, OF the 29th ult. Our friends of the south
really speak out.


We have copied to day from the NJ York Jour-
nal of Commerce, an article intended to shew the
impocy Of setting up manufactures in the Southern
States, and the great superiority of the free labor of
the North the slave labor of the South, in man.
ufacturing establishments To which we would re-
ply: the North is getting rich by its manufactures,
while the South, obstnaely depriving itself oftheir
aid heretofore, is daily growing poor, in spite of its
large capital Even in small town, it is
computed that we have half million lying idle for
want of profitable investments, and we have, more
over, eariully large portion of our population eth
er entirely idle, or employed not more than half
their time single cotton mandatory in our
town would, we are confident, materially alter the
aspect of our afairs-t would set the idle to work,
and gradually draw out the imprisoned boards of
wealth to nourish and revive dropping trade.
If the agricultural States of Pennsylvania, Delaware
and Maryland are rising to prosperity by manufac-
lures, why may not Virginia and North Carolina
After all that has been said to the contrary, we are
of opinion that slave labor may be advantageousy
employed should be necessary to resort to it-but
we have besides an abundant free population to
whom such employment would be blessing Let
us at least not be discouraged from making eff
fort, before resign ourselves to poverty and ruin

Mr.. Carter's book has just been published by the
Messrs Carvills under the above title. 1t is in two
handsome octave volumes, Of above 500 pages eacn,
on fine white paper, and beautiful type. About
one third of the work, as we have been informed, is
substantially new, consisting chiefly of letters writ
ten during the latter part of the tour, which were
not published. If would of course be superhuous
for US to speak of the talents and requirements Of the
author, or of the and luency Of his style: and
the public have already been made acquainted with
the plan and execution of large portion Of his book
which will no doubt be received with greater appro
baton and pleasure, from the improved and enlarg
ed form in which it now appears.


N. York Daily Adv

Chinese Literature e--This nation SO carefully iso-


lated from the rest Of the world possesses an Ency-
copeda in sixty four volumes. 1t was compiled by
Vang-hong-chan, a very distinguished Chinese wr-
ter, who lived under the reign of the Emperor Van
Pei, about the period at which the European Mis-
sonaries first visited China. The classification of
the materials for this work is very singular, and, as
we might we'll imagine bears but little analogy to
that Of the Encyclopedia of D'Alembert and Di1ero.

g. Celebrated Persons different tribes Of every ma
ton. q. Mystery Of the great Cyclic and Pakua. S.
Architecture. 6. instruments Of war, agriculture.
gardening and fishing. 7. Anatomy. s. Customs
and styles. 9. Game Of Chees and and other games


10. Ancient Chinese characters III. Botany and
natural history of different regions. 12. Mode of
wrangling fighting, and making arms. 1s. Mode
of irrigation. IA. Art of dancing. Is. Different
modes of preserving health and prolungng existence
l6. Quarrels and combats of cocks and bulls. IL.
Money and pieces of weighed silver.

the community, and good heads of families.

The Dedham Register gives an account of the
death of an individual from the smoke of lamp,
which was moi properly trimmed. 1t is a fact pro-
badly not known TO many persons who use lamps.
that when trimmed property, they never emit any
perceptibe smoke, and that when any smoke is vsi-
BILE, it is certain proof that the wick is too high,
and that the atmosphere about it Is becoming rapid
ly filled with particles of SCOT, most injurious to the
lungs, and to the eyes of every who breathes it.
The proper rule for adjusting the wick, is to raise





gree of flame, without the least visible smoke.

Resolued, That in our opinion no individual ought
to be put in nomination for ANY OFFICE, who is
not opposed to the present National Admnstra-
ton.


The New York Albion, of the 9th ult. gives the
following information


"Trcaty Of Ghent.-The Commissioners for set
tng the boundary, under the seventh article of the
above Treaty, after much labor, have made their
final reports to their respective Governments 1t is
gratifying to state, that the aforesaid Commissioners
have amicably determined by far the largest portion
of the line; two points only have been referred TO
the Governments, viz affecting st. Georges
Island, below the Sauld de Marie, in the water COM
muaicaton between Lakes Huron and SUPERIOR
Northwest of that Lake and Lac La Pue. The
Commissioners, it will be recollected, are ANTHONY
BARCLAY, Esq and Gen. P. B. PoRTER.'

subject, and you may thus give us new, and per-
haps better version Of this tale, if you are not yet

We have tried, in vain to publish all the phases

and there is silence in another quarter not alto

= The Nashville Committee have published an or
der Of Willie Blount Governor of Tennessee, dated
MAY IUa 1olf III WHiCH appears lInt SoFC'-
nor authorised General Jackson to 9 order out one
thousand militia infantry Of the sd Diuision for the
term of sir months, aaless discharged by the
order of The President Of The United States or you
may accept tender Of service Of the above number
Of volunteer infantry from the second division for
the aforesaid term" &c.


Gov. Blounts authority for this order, the mate
rial part of which we have quoted, are in the opinion
Of the Nashville Committee, the following letters.


WAR DEPARTMENT, Jan. tn, 1894.


"Sir.-You are authorised supply by militia
drafts, or BY volunteers, any deficiency which may
arise in the militia divisions under the command of
Major General jackson, and without referring on
this head, to this department..


1t may be we'll, that your exceency consult Gen.
Pinckney on such occasions as he can judge of the
whole number necessary to the attainment OF the
public objects.


(sisned) ]. ARMSTRONG"
'Tu Governor Blount.


(COPY.)


WAR DEPARTMENT, Jan. 81, 1914.


Sr---I had the honourto receive your Excellency's
letter of the 5th inst. My letter of the lth will
have anticipated your enquiries relative to further
detachments of Militia. The attention Of the Pay
master Of the army will be particularly directed to
the payment OF the troops who had been in service
from Tennessee.


| have the honour to be very respectfully, your


(SisnedD J. ARMSTRONG.
w. Blount Governor of Tennessee.


Now the advocates of fGeneral Jackson would have
us suppose that the President, through Gen. Arm
strong the above letters, authorised, calledu upon
the Governor, to call out the militia for six months,
in virtue OF act Of Congress, passed in April ID,
Of which the following is the 9Th section.


See first column second page, near the top, Of
this days Journal


In Gen. Armstrong; letters, nothing is said about
sic months, nor of the opinion Of the President Of
The United States that the public interest requires"
such term of service. The Governor was 6 au-
horised to supply by militia drafts or by volunteers
any defcieacy which mig ght arise in the militia,
called out for the usual three months service


We have just met with the following remarks
from the Cincinnati Gazette, and offer them nsteaC
ofany further comments of our own.
In this order, Gov. Blount fixes six months as tht
period of service. From whence did he derive au


hority TO do this? The Committee say from the or
der Of the War Department of January, 1914. Bu
the order gives the Governor no direction about tn
time of service. ltconides to him, simply the pow
er to call the militia, for the legal time, withou
specific requisition from the department.


The law of April 1874 which is quoted and relie
upon provides, that militia called into service, unde
the act ofl796, may, # IN heopinion Of the Presl
dent the United States, the public interest requir


1t, be detained in service six months. Were he dis
posed to do so the President could not legally cone


upon another the discretion, specially confded to hir
dy tasp. 1t was to his opinion alone, that the lay
r submitted the decision and the opinion of anothe
. could not be substituted. Had the President express
!. y authorised Gov Blunt to decide upon the propr
ETY. of making call for six months, it would hay
. been void and nugatory act He might as well hay

knowledge. We would have them evince the inter.
es they feel in this subject, by lurlhering the views


and aiding the Efforts Of those individuals, who have


time and abilities to devote to its advancement.


From the press, the pulpit and the forum. appeals


are occasionally made to the good sense OF the peo-
Pile IN favour of the dissemination of knowledge,


and these are not, cannot be made in vain. BY the
exertlons already made, our country has profted
signaly, and the moral and intellectual mprove-


ment evident to the observer, is an earnest of what


may be effected by continued and we'll directed ef.


forts. 1t is the general intelligence of the people,
as we'll as facility with which knowledge is actiuir-
ed, that distinguishes our happy country from the


less favored nations of Europe, whose yopth have
within their reach fewer of the advantages which are
free and common to the American youth.


BRITISH EAST INDIA coMPANY.---This singular
corporation,-. Mrs. Company" as the native Hin.
docs call it's of the anomalies Of which the
British Government presents us with good many
eXampes.-What subtracons it makes from the
commerce. of England, not to speak of its effects
India itself, may be guessed from few particulars
which we find in the Oriental Herald, in regard to
the resources ofthe Company. These consist, first
of all, in the profits of the exclusive trade with Chi
na which notwithstanding that trade is conducted in
the most eXtravagant manner, must necessarily be-
extremely productive TO the Company, from being
thus entirely in their hands and from the circum-
stance that Tea, the principal commodity brought
from that country, is an article used by nearly eve
ry individual in Great Brtain.--lts price in Eng
land, from this monopoly, is four times greater than
on the continent of Europe, or in America, or than
it could be obtained for in England ifthe trade
free. second source of profit is the revenue
arising in India itself from two monopolies,-one of
opium, the other Of salt on the first of which they
make profit of 700 or 800 per cent and on the
second, Of $50 per cent. By the one they destroy
the health well the morals of the people, over
China and the Malay islands as to the second they
force its manufacture by the greatest cruetes exer
cised on the natyes and then lay hisenormous tax
on the only condmen by which they can render pal
atable their miserable meal of boiled rice. The re-
naming revenue is from taxes justice, in the
shape of stamps, and from tax on land. This last
is not tenth OF its produce, which is considered
i'll England so undue portion for the support ofthe
Clergy,but OF eaths the other tenth being left
to the miserable cultivaor to subsst on, and turn-
Ish seed and materials for sowing and reaping an
other harvest This is really verifying the wits
saying, that :. the people in this world may be diyi
ded into hammers and anvils, those who are made
to smte, and those who are created 10 be smitten.
As the legislature will not permit the Company to
divide more than lOa per cent, it might be thought
at first sight, that this would have the happy effect
Of making them remit the taxes in India. But this
they never do. Though they cannot divide the
enormous revenue among themselves, they Can spend
il to enrich their relatives dependents and they
continue to drain the country to the lowest ebb, re-
paying the starving and oppressed natives by Civ
ing them the Trial by Jury The trade with India
mot including that with China.) involves an immense
annual loss their ships actually sailing at an expense
OF EGO ton, while smaller traders perform the voy
age at is ton. They continue to trade however,
because they chartered to trade, and must do it
as condition of their existence. Bengal is obliged
to pay the deficiency of Madras and Bombay, those
two presidencies, Notwithstanding their vast acces-
sons ofterritory, being inadequate to pay their own
expenses. The Company, witha, actually requires


loans from time to time, to pay its fixed dividend Of


l0a per cent. 1t is difficult to imagine mtre gi-
gantic system Of mischievous government, ruinous
monopoly, and bad economy, than this of sMrs.
Company which must one day justify the appella-
Ion bestowed on it, by expiring after too long life
of mixed decrepitude and mischievousness.

AMERICAN SYSTEM

full articles.headline: From a late English paper.
full articles.article:
About five O'Clock on Saturday morning steam
carriage, carrying nearly dozen of persons inside
and out, made its appearance on the Camden town
road. 1t proceeded through Kentish tswn and up
Highgate Hill, at the rate, as nearly as could CAL
culate, of 81 miles an hour, its velocity being the
same in ascending the hill the comparatively
level ground.-upon arriving at the summit Of the
hill opposite Holy terrace, the conductor turned his
ponderous vehicle, and Immediately commenced the
descent of the hill. at rate perhaps of four miles an
hour. Whether, however, arising from the unskl-
fulness of the manager, or from the defect of the
machinery, we cannot tell, his pace became gradu-
ally much greater, until the power of controlling its
impetus seeming to be almost lost, it was propelled
so violently over paved gutter, that one of the
wheels gave way and put an immediate termination
to its further progress by steam A horse was then
procured, and the machine dragged away upon its
five remaining wheels. We believe this is the first
steam carriage that has been brought fairly into ac-
ton before the public. In size it undoubtedly ap
pears unwiedy compared with the common stage
coach, being somewhat more broad and nearly twice


the length Of those vehicles; but it appeared. not


withstanding its bulk to be thoroughly under the con-
troll of the steerer until the disorder of the machine


ry, the weight of the body, proved too heavy for
the wheels.

We have copied to day from the NJ York Jour-
nal of Commerce, an article intended to shew the

ufacturing establishments To which we would re-
ply: the North is getting rich by its manufactures,

aid heretofore, is daily growing poor, in spite of its

computed that we have half million lying idle for

er entirely idle, or employed not more than half
their time single cotton mandatory in our
town would, we are confident, materially alter the

and gradually draw out the imprisoned boards of
wealth to nourish and revive dropping trade.
If the agricultural States of Pennsylvania, Delaware
and Maryland are rising to prosperity by manufac-
lures, why may not Virginia and North Carolina
After all that has been said to the contrary, we are

Mr.. Carter's book has just been published by the
Messrs Carvills under the above title. 1t is in two
handsome octave volumes, Of above 500 pages eacn,
on fine white paper, and beautiful type. About
one third of the work, as we have been informed, is
substantially new, consisting chiefly of letters writ
ten during the latter part of the tour, which were
not published. If would of course be superhuous
for US to speak of the talents and requirements Of the
author, or of the and luency Of his style: and
the public have already been made acquainted with
the plan and execution of large portion Of his book
which will no doubt be received with greater appro
baton and pleasure, from the improved and enlarg
ed form in which it now appears.


N. York Daily Adv

sonaries first visited China. The classification of

These statements are gathered from the official re-
cords, and are worth remembering.
The Dedham Register gives an account of the
death of an individual from the smoke of lamp,
which was moi properly trimmed. 1t is a fact pro-
badly not known TO many persons who use lamps.
that when trimmed property, they never emit any
perceptibe smoke, and that when any smoke is vsi-
BILE, it is certain proof that the wick is too high,
and that the atmosphere about it Is becoming rapid
ly filled with particles of SCOT, most injurious to the
lungs, and to the eyes of every who breathes it.
The proper rule for adjusting the wick, is to raise





gree of flame, without the least visible smoke.

ing resolve was passed:


Resolued, That in our opinion no individual ought
to be put in nomination for ANY OFFICE, who is
not opposed to the present National Admnstra-

The New York Albion, of the 9th ult. gives the
following information


"Trcaty Of Ghent.-The Commissioners for set
tng the boundary, under the seventh article of the
above Treaty, after much labor, have made their
final reports to their respective Governments 1t is
gratifying to state, that the aforesaid Commissioners
have amicably determined by far the largest portion
of the line; two points only have been referred TO
the Governments, viz affecting st. Georges
Island, below the Sauld de Marie, in the water COM
muaicaton between Lakes Huron and SUPERIOR
Northwest of that Lake and Lac La Pue. The
Commissioners, it will be recollected, are ANTHONY
BARCLAY, Esq and Gen. P. B. PoRTER.'

Do you observe that young lady with a compress
ed shape-and enormous French hat--a superabun-
dance of chains, bracelets, crosses, golden hearts,

subject, and you may thus give us new, and per-
haps better version Of this tale, if you are not yet
sick of IT, and think the world can be made to believe
it By all means, go on--Your tales, to be sure,
have aided our cause, giving the people glimpse
.fthe character your Hero and some ofhis friends.
But your wits are not yet exhausted, and your fab
rcations though of late rather short lived may keep
some fainting hearts spirits, and rouse the dor
mant energies of many g lukewarm Jacksonan, -
if we may be permitted to use the language of the
Richmond Enquirer, who, like some Delaware pat
riots, now advocate the claims of the General,
though it once declared his election would be "a
curse to the country


We have tried, in vain to publish all the phases
of the Palladium and Post story. 1t is worthy of
remark, that the Delaware member Of Congress,
mentioned in that tale has not appeared in public |;
and there is silence in another quarter not alto
geher indicative of any good to be obtained by the
Combination by further stirring the subject.
= The Nashville Committee have published an or
der Of Willie Blount Governor of Tennessee, dated
MAY IUa 1olf III WHiCH appears lInt SoFC'-
nor authorised General Jackson to 9 order out one
thousand militia infantry Of the sd Diuision for the
term of sir months, aaless discharged by the
order of The President Of The United States or you
may accept tender Of service Of the above number
Of volunteer infantry from the second division for
the aforesaid term" &c.


Gov. Blounts authority for this order, the mate
rial part of which we have quoted, are in the opinion
Of the Nashville Committee, the following letters.


WAR DEPARTMENT, Jan. tn, 1894.


"Sir.-You are authorised supply by militia
drafts, or BY volunteers, any deficiency which may
arise in the militia divisions under the command of
Major General jackson, and without referring on
this head, to this department..


1t may be we'll, that your exceency consult Gen.
Pinckney on such occasions as he can judge of the
whole number necessary to the attainment OF the
public objects.


(sisned) ]. ARMSTRONG"
'Tu Governor Blount.


(COPY.)


WAR DEPARTMENT, Jan. 81, 1914.


Sr---I had the honourto receive your Excellency's
letter of the 5th inst. My letter of the lth will
have anticipated your enquiries relative to further
detachments of Militia. The attention Of the Pay
master Of the army will be particularly directed to
the payment OF the troops who had been in service
from Tennessee.


| have the honour to be very respectfully, your


(SisnedD J. ARMSTRONG.
w. Blount Governor of Tennessee.


Now the advocates of fGeneral Jackson would have
us suppose that the President, through Gen. Arm
strong the above letters, authorised, calledu upon
the Governor, to call out the militia for six months,
in virtue OF act Of Congress, passed in April ID,
Of which the following is the 9Th section.


See first column second page, near the top, Of
this days Journal


In Gen. Armstrong; letters, nothing is said about
sic months, nor of the opinion Of the President Of
The United States that the public interest requires"
such term of service. The Governor was 6 au-
horised to supply by militia drafts or by volunteers
any defcieacy which mig ght arise in the militia,
called out for the usual three months service


We have just met with the following remarks
from the Cincinnati Gazette, and offer them nsteaC
ofany further comments of our own.
In this order, Gov. Blount fixes six months as tht
period of service. From whence did he derive au


hority TO do this? The Committee say from the or
der Of the War Department of January, 1914. Bu
the order gives the Governor no direction about tn
time of service. ltconides to him, simply the pow
er to call the militia, for the legal time, withou
specific requisition from the department.


The law of April 1874 which is quoted and relie
upon provides, that militia called into service, unde
the act ofl796, may, # IN heopinion Of the Presl
dent the United States, the public interest requir


1t, be detained in service six months. Were he dis
posed to do so the President could not legally cone


upon another the discretion, specially confded to hir
dy tasp. 1t was to his opinion alone, that the lay
r submitted the decision and the opinion of anothe
. could not be substituted. Had the President express
!. y authorised Gov Blunt to decide upon the propr
ETY. of making call for six months, it would hay
. been void and nugatory act He might as well hay

knowledge. We would have them evince the inter.
es they feel in this subject, by lurlhering the views


and aiding the Efforts Of those individuals, who have


time and abilities to devote to its advancement.


From the press, the pulpit and the forum. appeals


are occasionally made to the good sense OF the peo-
Pile IN favour of the dissemination of knowledge,


and these are not, cannot be made in vain. BY the
exertlons already made, our country has profted
signaly, and the moral and intellectual mprove-


ment evident to the observer, is an earnest of what


may be effected by continued and we'll directed ef.


forts. 1t is the general intelligence of the people,
as we'll as facility with which knowledge is actiuir-
ed, that distinguishes our happy country from the


less favored nations of Europe, whose yopth have
within their reach fewer of the advantages which are
free and common to the American youth.


BRITISH EAST INDIA coMPANY.---This singular
corporation,-. Mrs. Company" as the native Hin.
docs call it's of the anomalies Of which the
British Government presents us with good many
eXampes.-What subtracons it makes from the
commerce. of England, not to speak of its effects
India itself, may be guessed from few particulars
which we find in the Oriental Herald, in regard to
the resources ofthe Company. These consist, first
of all, in the profits of the exclusive trade with Chi
na which notwithstanding that trade is conducted in
the most eXtravagant manner, must necessarily be-
extremely productive TO the Company, from being
thus entirely in their hands and from the circum-
stance that Tea, the principal commodity brought
from that country, is an article used by nearly eve
ry individual in Great Brtain.--lts price in Eng
land, from this monopoly, is four times greater than
on the continent of Europe, or in America, or than
it could be obtained for in England ifthe trade
free. second source of profit is the revenue
arising in India itself from two monopolies,-one of
opium, the other Of salt on the first of which they
make profit of 700 or 800 per cent and on the
second, Of $50 per cent. By the one they destroy
the health well the morals of the people, over
China and the Malay islands as to the second they
force its manufacture by the greatest cruetes exer
cised on the natyes and then lay hisenormous tax
on the only condmen by which they can render pal
atable their miserable meal of boiled rice. The re-
naming revenue is from taxes justice, in the
shape of stamps, and from tax on land. This last
is not tenth OF its produce, which is considered
i'll England so undue portion for the support ofthe
Clergy,but OF eaths the other tenth being left
to the miserable cultivaor to subsst on, and turn-
Ish seed and materials for sowing and reaping an
other harvest This is really verifying the wits
saying, that :. the people in this world may be diyi
ded into hammers and anvils, those who are made
to smte, and those who are created 10 be smitten.
As the legislature will not permit the Company to
divide more than lOa per cent, it might be thought
at first sight, that this would have the happy effect
Of making them remit the taxes in India. But this
they never do. Though they cannot divide the
enormous revenue among themselves, they Can spend
il to enrich their relatives dependents and they
continue to drain the country to the lowest ebb, re-
paying the starving and oppressed natives by Civ
ing them the Trial by Jury The trade with India
mot including that with China.) involves an immense
annual loss their ships actually sailing at an expense
OF EGO ton, while smaller traders perform the voy
age at is ton. They continue to trade however,
because they chartered to trade, and must do it
as condition of their existence. Bengal is obliged
to pay the deficiency of Madras and Bombay, those
two presidencies, Notwithstanding their vast acces-
sons ofterritory, being inadequate to pay their own
expenses. The Company, witha, actually requires


loans from time to time, to pay its fixed dividend Of


l0a per cent. 1t is difficult to imagine mtre gi-
gantic system Of mischievous government, ruinous
monopoly, and bad economy, than this of sMrs.
Company which must one day justify the appella-
Ion bestowed on it, by expiring after too long life
of mixed decrepitude and mischievousness.
